**3. :fas-info-circle: Proposed improvement is notInScope, but if implemented it will break documentation, reject?**
</div>



tl;dr technically `notInScope` but if implemented, strays from expected and **currently** documented behaviour

As stated in the title, one of the issues raised in my team's PE is a notInScope:
We have a fuzzy search feature that returns the top 5 closest results.
However, this returned list is not ordered according to the "close-ness" to the query string, but ordered in the current comparator for our `sortedList` aka `sort` feature.
Note that our sorting is persistent, be it after `list` or `find`

The DG and UG does explicitly state that the results are unordered.
So I feel that it is suitable for `notInScope`. 

However, assuming that we did implement this and maybe also state in DG/UG that for our fuzzy search it is sorted according to  the "closeness" of the query technically it can be claimed that it is a feature-flaw because it violate's sort's expected behaviour. 


</panel>

> Here's a possible implementation that seems clean to me, atleast for Input Processing.
> 
> 1. Have a common parent for all classes that will handle all exceptions
> 2. All other classes will propagate their errors to the parent (by rethrowing the errors, possibly create custom exceptions)
> 3. Handle errors at the parent, eg. print error message to CLI
> 
> Feel free to share any thoughts.

@jovnc 
Does a "common parent" mean that the class will extend the exception handler?

To OP @Ruinim as well:
My views are that although having a dedicated exception handler might be "cleaner",
it could make the code less readable. i.e. the person reading the code does not get to see what exception is expected.
(Just imagine, if you have 20 exceptions, how do you know for that part of the code which exception(s) might hit ?) 

Of course, you could make it so that every exception is its own method which would reflect the expected exception.
But then there is a separate issue of what if in different parts of your code you would want different behaviour for the same exception?

Also, handling exceptions ASAP instead of passing it on to the caller function so that your debug log is not messy. 


</panel>

I believe composition and aggregation do imply navigability. It is mentioned in the notes that:

<div align="center">
<img width="677" height="138" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ba48681e-a0e3-4799-839a-369d2c2e1ccc" />
</div>

And we can use your examples on bookshelves and chessboard to see if aggregation and composition do imply navigability or not.

### Aggregation
Bookshelves need to know the books it holds as such they need to store it as a field, for example:

'''Java
public class Bookshelf ``{``
    private Book[] books;
``}``
'''

So this way, aggregation does imply navigability. I say this is aggregation because if we "delete" the bookshelf, these books can still "live" and be used.

### Composition
Similarly, chessboard might be implemented like this:

'''Java
public class Chessboard ``{``
    private Tiles[] tiles;
``}``
'''

Again, this composition relationship imply navigability as Chessboard object holds Tiles object as a field thus forming a structural relationship. I say this is composition because if we "delete" the chessboard, it would not make sense for the tiles to continue "living" on its own.

And so I believe you do not need to draw additional lines to show navigability if you are already using aggregation or composition.
</panel>

From [this source](https://www.softwareideas.net/sequence-diagram-opt-vs-alt) (I'm not sure if it's applicable in our course, though I assume it is since UML notations are agreed upon) `alt` must contain at least **two** mutually exclusive paths. In comparison, `opt` only has **one**. So I believe notation-wise, having just one path for `alt` is not acceptable.

Following up on these questions;

> 1. Does this imply that an alternative must have at least 2 partitions, and that one of them must be executed?

As mentioned above, I do believe `alt` must have minimally **two** partitions/paths, but it is ok if none is executed, as mention in the notes;

> No more than one alternative partitions be executed in an alt frame. That is, **it is acceptable for none of the alternative partitions to be executed** but it is not acceptable for multiple partitions to be executed.

For this question, I assume you meant removing `process()` from `Bar`. This will not cause a compile error and it will not break the inheritance. Just like what @dingf3ng mentioned, `process()` is not an abstract method in `Foo`, so removing `process()` from `Bar` will only cause any call to `Bar`'s `process()` to invoke the one in `Foo`.

If you meant removing `process()` from `Foo`, then compilation error **could** arise if you wrote `@override` above `process()` in `Bar`, like:

'''Java
public class Bar ``{``
    @Override
    public void process() ``{``...``}``
``}``
'''

Since the `@Override` annotation is meant to help you check whether you are overriding a parent's method correctly. Else, I don't think any error will arise if you remove `process()` from `Foo`.
</panel>

**12. :fas-info-circle: Is it just me or is the example .yml file in the A-CI increment really misleading?**
</div>

In the [A-CI iP increment](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/schedule/week5/project.html#a-ci), [this `.yml` file](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/schedule/week5/project.html#a-ci:~:text=workflow%20specified%20by-,this%20.yml%20file,-is%20a%20good) was given as a suitable example for our project. However, the [accompanying guide](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/githubActions.html) had almost no information on what the file was for, what the steps were doing or how to set it up.

(The full `.yml` file for convenient reference: 
'''yml
name: Java CI

on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  build:
    strategy:
      matrix:
        platform: [ubuntu-latest, macos-latest, windows-latest]
    runs-on: $``{`` matrix.platform ``}``

    steps:
      - name: Set up repository
        uses: actions/checkout@master

      - name: Set up repository
        uses: actions/checkout@master
        with:
          ref: master

      - name: Merge to master
        run: git checkout --progress --force $``{`` github.sha ``}``

      - name: Validate Gradle Wrapper
        uses: gradle/actions/wrapper-validation@v3

      - name: Setup JDK 17
        uses: actions/setup-java@v4
        with:
          distribution: 'zulu'
          java-version: '17'
          java-package: jdk+fx

      - name: Build and check with Gradle
        run: ./gradlew check

      - name: Install dos2unix on Linux
        if: runner.os == 'Linux'
        run: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y dos2unix

      - name: Install dos2unix on macOS
        if: runner.os == 'macOS'
        run: brew install dos2unix

      - name: Perform IO redirection test (*NIX or macOS)
        if: runner.os == 'Linux' || runner.os == 'macOS'
        working-directory: $``{`` github.workspace ``}``/text-ui-test
        run: ./runtest.sh

      - name: Perform IO redirection test (Windows)
        if: always() && runner.os == 'Windows'
        working-directory: $``{`` github.workspace ``}``/text-ui-test
        shell: cmd
        run: runtest.bat
'''  
)

Firstly, from what I can tell (mostly with gpt), the 3 checkout steps are redundant â€“ only the last one matters, and it also has a really misleading name, "Merge to master", when it's not doing any merging at all. Furthermore, the [v4/v5 github checkout action](https://github.com/actions/checkout) already checks out the commit that triggered the workflow by default, so a simple checkout would have been sufficient.

Secondly, the "Validate Gradle Wrapper" step fails if you did not commit your `gradle-wrapper.jar` file. I'm not sure if I missed something, or did something weird that most students wouldn't naturally do, but I followed [this part](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/schedule/week2/topics.html#t2l6-omitting-files-from-revision-control) of the Topics on Revision Control and removed the `gradle-wrapper.jar` file from Git, which of course causes the wrapper validation to fail.

Lastly, [this documentation](https://github.com/gradle/actions/blob/main/docs/wrapper-validation.md) seems to say that the `setup-gradle` action from `v4` onwards already automatically validates wrapper jar files, so it seems that that step is also unnecessary and could just be a comment?
</panel>

(Just imagine, if you have 20 exceptions, how do you know for that part of the code which exception(s) might hit ?)
>

Sorry, maybe using a wrong terminology here, as it can get confused with OOP inheritance. 

What I actually had in mind was something like having a main class responsible for input handling, which would also be the central place to catch and manage exceptions. That way, all the other classes can propagate their errors up to this class, and the decision for how to handle them (e.g., logging or printing error messages) is made in one place.

'''java
class A ``{``
    try ``{``
        // handle input here
    ``}`` catch (ExceptionA e) ``{``
        // centralized handling
    ``}`` catch (ExceptionB e) ``{``

    ``}``
``}``
'''

The idea is just to keep exception handling consistent by managing it in a central layer, rather than having every class deal with it separately.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/29#issuecomment-3198828603" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**9 :fas-comment:**

> https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/29#issuecomment-3196385778
> @jovnc 
> I see, I think my point about readability and having different behaviour for the same exception in different parts of the code would still apply as mentioned to OP
> 

I have considered that approach, and it definitely is sound. However, I had some troubles implementing that and thus stuck to the "global" exception handling approach.

Here's a a few things you might want to note when implementing that:
- how should you handle the exception in child classes? 
- eg. you have a handleTask function that uses a child class to parse the input string, create the task, etc. How should the child class propagate the error message up? Do you just crash the program, or should handleTask return an error message instead

I think it also ultimately depends on how you structure your program, to see which solution fits best for your use case.
</panel>

I considered the implementation you mentioned, where I handle it in the child class, by returning a 'String' as an error message, instead of propagating the error up the hierarchy.

However, it seemed awkward to return a 'String' to me, as that's not what I would expect the function to return. From the 'parent' class point of view, it seems like there was no error to begin with (even though it should be an error, that is handled).

Furthermore, what if the error occurs in a class with a function that doesn't return a 'String'? eg. DateUtils to parse date strings, where the function should return LocalDate object.

But yes, I do agree that handling errors where it first occurs does seem cleaner in terms on thinking about the logic of it. I guess there are tradeoffs to each implementation.

</panel>

Hi, it appears that your tag for Level-5 and Level-6 does not belong to the `master` branch in your repository. Your previous tags do not have this issue, thus it can be picked up in iP dashboard page.

Level-5 tag:

1. delete the tag locally

`git tag -d Level-5`

2. delete the tag from the remote

`git push origin --delete Level-5`

3. find the relevant commit you want to tag it

`git log --oneline`

4. tag the relevant commit

`git tag <COMMIT-HASH>`

5. push the tag

`git push origin Level-5`

If I'm not wrong, `data/rio.ser` should be placed at the root of the directory, not under `resources` directory

When running from a JAR file:
The resources folder and its contents are bundled inside the JAR file. A JAR is essentially a zip archive. The path `resources/data/rio.ser` no longer points to a file on the operating system's file system. Instead, it's an entry within the JAR archive itself. As a result, any code trying to access it as a java.io.File will fail, usually with a `FileNotFoundException`.


</panel>

Fundamentally, having a bidirectional arrow has a different meaning from two arrows.

Bidirectional arrow means that `Cat` and `Person` are navigable from each other, ie. if `PersonA` is linked to `CatB`, then `CatB` must be linked to `PersonA`.

Two arrows mean two distinct, independent relationships, eg. `PersonA` is linked to `CatB`, but `CatB` is not necessarily linked to `PersonA`, it can be linked to `PersonC` instead

So, it really depends on what message you are trying to convey from the class diagram.
</panel>

**28 :fas-comment:**

In the context of Java, Java is OOP in nature, thus everything has to live inside classes (ignoring Java 25).

Thus, the global variable has to live inside another class `C`. Here's an example below.

'''java
class C ``{``
    public static int GLOBAL_VAR = 10;
``}``

class A ``{``
    public void foo() ``{``
        System.out.println("GLOBAL_VAR: " + C.GLOBAL_VAR);
    ``}``
``}``

class B ``{``
    public void bar() ``{``
        System.out.println("GLOBAL_VAR: " + C.GLOBAL_VAR);
    ``}``
``}``
'''

From the class diagram perspective, this would mean A and B depend on C.

It may seem like there is no coupling here, since the A has no direct arrows to B. However, consider the case where I want to update A to print `20` instead of `10`. Because they rely on the same global variable, I would unknowingly be changing the B to print `20` as well.




</panel>

</panel>

As you merged `master` branch to `branch-A-Streams` branch, this means that all code that is found in the `master` branch will be merged into the `branch-A-Streams` branch. Since the `master` branch itself does not contain the code for streams feature (as we/you did your work for streams in a separate branch), therefore the `master` branch does not contain code that utilise streams.

To proceed to add the code that utilises streams to your `master` branch, since the code that utilises stream is found in your `branch-A-Streams` branch, you can either (follow option 2 instead since the increment suggests doing it this way):
1. `git checkout master` to switch to your `master` branch
- proceed to `git merge branch-A-Streams --no-ff` to merge code done in `branch-A-Streams` branch (code that utilises streams) to your `master` branch 
- `git push origin master` to push your local repo's `master` branch to your remote repo
- note that this approach is **not recommended** since this increment is to get you to practice creating pull requests (PR) in your own forked repository

2. create a PR within your fork on GitHub (from `branch-A-Streams` to `master` branch)- merge the PR on GitHub and choose the Create merge commit option when merging
- this will cause the `master` branch of your local repo to fall behind that of your fork, therefore, you need to sync the local `master` with the remote `master` branch 
- to do that, switch to the local `master` branch and then pull the updated `master` branch from your fork e.g.,
```
git checkout master
git pull origin master
```
- lastly, tag the merge commit as usual, and push to the fork

p.s. the above information can be found in [here](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/schedule/week5/project.html#3-add-increments-as-prs-a-assertions-a-codequality-a-streams)

1. delete the `A-BetterGUI` tag on your local repo

To achieve that you can do the following commands
```
git tag -d A-BetterGUI // deletes the tag on your local repo
git push origin --delete A-BetterGUI // deletes the tag on your remote repo
git tag HEAD~2 A-BetterGui // since your merge PR commit was the 3rd most recent commit, we tag HEAD~2 instead
git push origin --tags // pushes the updated tag from your local repo to your remote repo
```

Edit: change `HEAD~1` to `HEAD~2` since merge PR commit is now the 3rd most recent commit

> Is this because Action is an abstract class, hence it need not explicitly show its inherited `repeat()` method?

Not sure whether there is a source for this (maybe it was covered in a tutorial or nested somewhere in the textbook) but for Class Diagrams, methods (in this case `repeat()` method) are only included in the child class if it has been overridden. So, to answer this question, no, it is not because `Action` is an abstract class, but because `Action` class does not modify / override the `repeat()` method inherited from the `Repeatable` interface. 

It is totally possible for an abstract class `Action` to override the `repeat()` method and thus we would need to include the `repeat()` method under its operations, in the class diagram. Hence, it is not to do with the fact that `Action` is an abstract class but because it does not override the `repeat()` method.

> If the `repeat()` method was shown inside the abstract class, will it be deemed wrong?

That would depend on whether `Action` class did in fact override the `repeat()` method and have its own implementation. Judging from the code snippet attached above, it seems as if the `Action` class does not override the `repeat()` method, thus including it in the abstract class would be incorrect, since it would suggest that `Action` class did in fact override the `repeat()` method and have its own implementation

~~**Note:** my answer is based off the understanding that including inherited methods in child classes means that they override the parent class's methods, so I may be incorrect~~

Edit: This was covered in one of the tutorials, T8, on drawing UML class diagrams
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/582#issuecomment-3588609282" expanded>

**26 :fas-comment:**

@TheresiaOng @iZUMi-kyouka I disagree that the activation bar inside the `alt` box should be continuous (i.e. they should be separated). In the question, we either execute `f.increase(2)` or `f.increase(3)` which are two different `increase(x)` method calls. Activation bars show the period for which a method is being executed. By joining the activation bars, we are saying that both `increase(2)` and `increase(3)` methods have the same activation bar and are being executed for the same period, which should not be the case given that we either execute `increase(2)` or `increase(3)`, both of which are two different function invocations. Hence, I believe separating the activation bars is correct here.

As for the TaskList sequence diagram shown in the video, the reason why the activation bar is not being separated is because the `generate()` method either calls `getTask()` method or invokes the `Task` constructor. Hence, it would be correct to not split the activation bar for that question.
</panel>

From this information alone, I would think that this is a dependency.  A `Consumer` is a function that performs operation on many `ClassB`. You may have such function without having any actual reference to `ClassB` or even `List&lt;ClassB>`. However, `ClassA` could still depend on, for example, instance methods in `ClassB` since you may call these methods in the `Consumer`. e.g. `Consumer&lt;List&lt;ClassB>> c = lst -&gt; ``{`` lst.stream().map(ClassB::someClassMethod); ``}```;

<div slot="header">

**5. :fas-info-circle: Checkstyle does not exclude checks for missing Javadoc for some constructors**
</div>

## Background

The [tP upstream repo (AB3) `checkstyle.xml`](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/tp/blob/bd6718b2d6d7ca209ce08a9c33955687dfff97d9/config/checkstyle/checkstyle.xml#L411) explicitly excludes checking for missing Javadoc header comments for constructors.

According to [this StackOverflow answer on ignoring Javadoc validation for constructors](https://stackoverflow.com/a/32319169), the way the AB3 handles such exclusion appears to be correct.

## Problem

Not all constructors are actually excluded by this Checkstyle check.

Based on some light testing, it appears that any changes to constructor implementation beyond just having straightforward `this.&lt;fieldName> = &lt;paramName>;` lines will cause Checkstyle to no longer ignore that constructor for Javadoc-related checks.

For example:

* The constructor below (taken from base AB3) is ignored by Checkstyle (that is, Checkstyle will _not_ raise an error saying it is missing a Javadoc comment).

'''java
public FindCommand(NameContainsKeywordsPredicate predicate) ``{``
    this.predicate = predicate;
``}``
'''

* The constructors below will _not_ be ignored by Checkstyle (that is, Checkstyle will raise an error saying it is missing a Javadoc comment).

'''java
public FindCommand(NameContainsKeywordsPredicate predicate) ``{``
    requireNonNull(predicate);
    this.predicate = predicate;
``}``
// OR
public FindCommand(NameContainsKeywordsPredicate predicate) ``{``
    this.predicate = predicate;
    int i = 1 + 1;
``}``
'''

Does anyone know how to amend Checkstyle to exclude _all_ constructors from Javadoc-related checks (other than manually adding the file name and line no. for each constructor to `suppressions.xml`)?

PS: I have checked (using `git diff`) that my `checkstyle.xml` and `build.gradle` (that is, the version no. of Checkstyle I am using) is the same as AB3.

Just in case it's relevant:

* I'm running checkstyle using `./gradlew clean checkstyleMain checkstyleTest` inside IntelliJ IDEA Ultimate 2025.2.3.
* I'm on MacOS 26.0.1.

(Whether such constructors should/must have Javadoc header comments for the tP is discussed separately in #372.)
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/372" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**6. :fas-info-circle: Should tP public constructors have Javadoc comments?**
</div>

Based on [the course's Java coding standard](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/index.html#comments), it appears that Javadoc header comments are required for all public constructors, as constructors are not one of the two exceptions listed (getters/setters and overriding methods in certain cases). 

Though arguably, for straightforward constructors, it might count as self-explanatory and thus not require Javadoc header comments under the [Google Java style guide exception for "self-explanatory members"](https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s7.3.1-javadoc-exception-self-explanatory) (I know the [textbook](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/se-book-adapted/chapters/cppToJava.html#:~:text=Constructors%20are%20not%20members) defines "members" to exclude constructors, but I'm not sure if Google is using the same definition. Even if it is, I guess one could argue that excluding Javadoc comments for straightforward constructors can follow the spirit of this rule, even if it doesn't follow the letter.)

Also, in the tP upstream repo (AB3),

* Some constructors, such as [the constructor for the `FindCommand.java` class](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/tp/blob/bd6718b2d6d7ca209ce08a9c33955687dfff97d9/src/main/java/seedu/address/logic/commands/FindCommand.java#L23), do not have any Javadoc header comments.
* The [checkstyle.xml settings](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/tp/blob/bd6718b2d6d7ca209ce08a9c33955687dfff97d9/config/checkstyle/checkstyle.xml#L411) explicitly exclude checking for missing Javadoc header comments for constructors. (
    * I note that Checkstyle does not exclude _all_ constructors from this check, I'll create a separate forum post on this issue in the spirit of [the course's website instruction not to hijack other threads](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/admin/appendixD-help.html#:~:text=Don't%20hijack%20other%20threads).

Should we add Javadoc header comments to (a) the public constructors we add to our tP repo and (b) existing public constructors from the upstream repo (if we do not change their implementation significantly)? Or is this a subjective thing which each team should make its own decision on, after weighing pros and cons?

In my opinion, for (a), there is low cost to doing so, and as such, it is probably a good idea still add Javadoc header comments as a good practice.

However, for (b), it feels like quite a substantial effort that I'm not sure is worth it. While adding such header comments can have some benefits (better understanding of the AB-3 code base + more practice writing Javadoc header comments), I think it is outweighed by the time spent doing so that could be better spent on other aspects of the tP aligned with more important learning objectives.
</panel>

**17 :fas-comment:**
</div>

TL;DR - Recommend making classes completely immutable, or else avoid using mutable fields in `equals(Object)` and `hashCode()`

Sorry, this is very long, because I ended up on a rabbit hole one day when I was searching how to best design tests for `equals(Object)` methods in Java.

> "Classes should be immutable unless thereâ€™s a very good reason to make them mutable."
> 
> \- Joshua Bloch's _Effective Java_ (3rd Ed.), p. 86

_Note: You can legally get the full eBook of_ Effective Java _from [NUS Libraries](https://go.exlibris.link/Z8nvcMVB) for free._

Immutability brings various advantages, such as:

* Simplifies issues regarding state.
* Can be shared between classes without worrying about [aliasing bugs](https://martinfowler.com/bliki/AliasingBug.html).
* Thread-safe.
* Easy failure atomicity (which means that when a method is called and throws some exception, the objects should be in the same state as it was prior to the method call).

(Source for above points: Bloch's _Effective Java_, Items 17 and 76)

The main disadvantage of immutable classes are mainly memory and performance related (because you must construct a new class whenever modifying any field). However, I think most tP projects are small scale enough that this will not be an issue. Regardless, we should [avoid pre-mature optimization](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/schedule/week5/topics.html#implementation-code-quality-readability-intermediate-avoid-premature-optimizations).

Immutability is especially important when using `equals(Object)` (and `hashCode()`).

Using mutable fields when comparing objects in `equals(Object)` or generating its hash code is discouraged due to the issues you mentioned. For a more detailed discussion, you can refer to [this article on writing equality methods in Java by Odersky et al.](https://www.artima.com/articles/how-to-write-an-equality-method-in-java) (under "Pitfall #&#8203;3").

&lt;!-- &#8203; is an invisible character, added to avoid addressing a GitHub issue. Credit to https://stackoverflow.com/a/52463489. -->

The [EqualsVerifier library](https://github.com/jqno/equalsverifier) designed for Java unit testing of `equals` and `hashCode` enforces that fields that `equals` depends on should be `final` (source: [EqualsVerifier manual page on immutability](https://jqno.nl/equalsverifier/manual/immutability/)), and in fact, even recommends you make the class itself or its `equals` method `final` (source: [EqualsVerifier manual page on "Making things final"](https://jqno.nl/equalsverifier/manual/final/)).

More generally, you should try to ensure that you follows the general contract for `Object#equals(Object)` and `Object#hashCode()`, which is detailed in the [Java API for java.lang.Object](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/Object.html). This can help avoid some hard-to-fix bugs using collections, especially hash-based ones. There's a more detailed discussion on how to ensure you fulfil this contract (and common pitfalls) in _Effective Java_ Items 10 and 11. EqualsVerifier can help check if your code follow this contract.

If you want an extended discussion on how to design a good `equals(Object)` method implementation, I recommend [this relevant video by Jan Ouwens](https://youtu.be/pNJ_O10XaoM), who's behind the EqualsVerifier library mentioned earlier. Bloch's _Effective Java_ is also a pretty good book in my opinion!

(Note: Base AB-3 does not strictly follow the Java `equals` and `hashCode` general contracts. I think in some cases, perhaps the costs of following the contract outweighs the benefits. For instance, it is highly unlikely anyone would put any of the `Parser` subclasses in a hash-based collection, so overriding `hashCode` for these subclasses is unnecessary even though `equals` is overridden.)

</panel>

If an exception is thrown, I suspect there might be a more serious bug behind it. Perhaps this is beyond the effort expected for PE, but since you have the stacktrace, maybe you can review the repo code and try to find the bug yourself. Alternatively, you can try testing further to see if, say, there has been some corruption to the data.

Even if you find some bigger issue(s) behind it, you can still file this terminal output bug as a separate report, since the website says there's no penalty for duplicate reports.

> So, it is safe to assume that 100's of lines that was thrown due to 1 exception could 'worry' the user despite the UI operating normally?

In my opinion, this is reasonable. I cannot speak on behalf of my teammates or my team as a whole, but personally if I got a bug report about this for PE, I would likely accept it. 

The only case where I think this might not be a bug is if the developers mention somewhere (such as in a separate line of terminal output or in the UG) that this error output can be safely ignored. 

> If so, would it be appropriate to label it as
>
> * Functionality bug

Sounds fine. Alternatively, if you think the best way to fix this problem is to inform users in the UG that such terminal output can be safely ignored, then it's likely `type.DocumentationBug`.  (Though I can't really think of a scenario this is the best option.)

> * Severy.low (because it doesn't impact the user)

I'm admittedly not really sure about this. I think it might be `severity.VeryLow` since it's arguably cosmetic.

On the other hand, some other factors might perhaps make it higher severity:

* Is such output common? For example, is this exception thrown everytime a commonly used command is run?
* Upon seeing this output, is a reasonable user likely to...
  * ...think her previous command(s) was (were) unsuccessful?
  * ...take some action to attempt to rectify the (perceived) error? If so, what is the effect of such actions?
* Might the message alarm an average user enough to decide not to continue using the product?
* How is the target audience specifically likely to interpret this command? How much technical knowledge about stacktraces are they likely/assumed to have? How might this affect their level of alarm or the actions they take in response to the output?
</panel>

For severity, personally I would consider the following factors:

* How important is this diagram to developers? If you were, say, a new developer coming to this app, how much would this diagram hinder your ability to understand the existing code base and make changes?

**9. :fas-info-circle: Will we be penalised for using enums instead of subclassing Task?**
</div>

Will we be penalised for using enums instead of subclassing Task?

In [week 2](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/schedule/week2/project.html#4-add-increments-while-committing-frequently-level-0-level-1-level-2-level-3-level-4-a-textuitesting-level-5-level-6-a-enums-fri-aug-22nd-1600), A-Inheritance was only said to be "recommended", and not in the list of compulsory Additions. I took the optional A-Enums as encouragement to do
```
enum TaskType ``{``
    T, D, E
``}``
```
instead.

In [week 3's A-MoreOOP](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/schedule/week3/project.html#4-add-increments-a-moreoop-a-packages-a-gradle-a-junit-a-jar), it was said:

> Minimal: Extract the following classes:
> - Ui: deals with interactions with the user
> - Storage: deals with loading tasks from the file and saving tasks in the file
> - Parser: deals with making sense of the user command
> - TaskList: contains the task list e.g., it has operations to add/delete tasks in the list

I only realised late in week 6 that subclassing Task was given as an example ("e.g." not "i.e."). (I do have other inheritances (`Main extends Application, DialogBox extends HBox`), and I daresay my "code [is overall] divided into classes in a sensible way")

> Reasonable use of OOP e.g., at least some use of inheritance, code divided into classes in a sensible way (e.g., Ui, Storage, Parser, Todo, Deadline, Event etc.)


~~I now see that subclasses is the slightly better approach if more Task types are added, but I guess splitting into subclasses can add overhead in a small project, ending up with more files, more boilerplate, and more places to update when requirements change. Keeping everything in one Task with a TaskType enum is simpler to maintain early on, avoids class sprawl, and makes storage/serialization more straightforward.~~

(I promise to take this lesson of OOP to my TP, and use the extra time to revise CS2103 theory for exams if I don't have to refactor my code.)

</panel>

**1. :fas-info-circle: Should equals() and hashCode() only include immutable fields, or should I make everything immutable?**
</div>

After editing **AB3**, we introduced an `Events` class that stores a `HashSet&lt;Member>`.  
Each `Member` object also stores its own `eventRoles` â€” so there are multiple references between `Event` and `Member`.

Because of this two-way relationship, we decided to make these objects **mutable**.  
However, we soon realised that editing a `Member` (for example, adding an event role) would change its state, which in turn **changes its `hashCode()`**.  This caused confusing bugs â€” like members disappearing from `HashSet`s or duplicate entries appearing after updates.

---

## ðŸ§  The two designs Iâ€™m considering

1. **Immutable identity-based equality**  
   - Only include *immutable fields* (like `name`, `phone`, `email`) in `equals()` and `hashCode()`.  
   - Mutable fields (like `eventRoles`) are excluded to avoid breaking collections.

2. **Fully immutable objects**  
   - Make both `Member` and `Event` immutable.  
   - Replace objects entirely instead of mutating them when changes happen.

---

## â“ My question

Which approach is generally more robust or better?

- Is it fine to define equality only on immutable â€œidentityâ€ fields, even if two objects that differ in mutable fields will still be considered equal?  
- Or is it better practice to go all-in on immutability to avoid inconsistencies entirely?

Would really appreciate any design insights or best-practice advice
</panel>

**7. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡Free yourself from launch sdkman**
</div>

For Mac user, every time you restart the terminal, you need to initialize sdkman otherwise the jdk version will not match and will encounter error when using gradle. Here is a solution I found:

add this line to `~/.zshrc`
```
# SDKMAN initialization
source "$HOME/.sdkman/bin/sdkman-init.sh"
```
and restart `~/.zshrc`

the solution:
1. stop tracking
- single file: `git rm --cached filename`
- folder: `git rm -r --cached foldername`
2. commit this change: `git commit -m "Stop tracking filename"`
3. push to remote: `git push`

**14 :fas-comment:**
</div>

I think this is not a problem about coding standard but about usage.
In cases where:

1. Programmer intend to propagate exceptions upward **only after** the finally block is called to clean up AND
2. The function at current level cannot handle the exception

In this case, *a try with just finally* is appropriate and not violate code standard.

So it depends on how your reviewee use it.

---
An example to illustrate point 1:
'''java
public static void main(String[] args) ``{``
    try ``{``
        System.out.println("In try");
        int x = 5 / 0;   // ArithmeticException
    ``}`` finally ``{``
        System.out.println("In finally");
    ``}``
    System.out.println("After try-finally");
``}``
'''
will print
'''
In try
In finally   &lt;-- here the finally block is executed first before the exception handled
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.ArithmeticException: / by zero
'''

Also some good resource to look at: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2614473/does-it-make-sense-to-do-try-finally-without-catch
</panel>

git remote -v
You should now see both origin and upstream. (which you do)
git fetch upstream
Now you should see upstream/add-gradle-support when you run: (which you do)
git branch -a
create a local branch that tracks it:
git switch -c add-gradle-support upstream/add-gradle-support
This means:

-c â†’ create new local branch

name it add-gradle-support

base it on upstream/add-gradle-support

Now youâ€™re â€œonâ€ that branch.
Merge into master

Switch back to master:

git switch master


Merge the Gradle support branch into master:

git merge --no-ff add-gradle-support -m "Merge add-gradle-support into master"


At this point, your master branch has Gradle support.
Push both branches to your fork:

git push origin master
git push origin add-gradle-support
Now that Gradle support is merged, you should see new files in your repo:

build.gradle

settings.gradle

gradlew and gradlew.bat

gradle/ folder

From here:

Run your program with Gradle:

./gradlew run

Consider using [Github Desktop](https://docs.github.com/en/desktop/installing-and-authenticating-to-github-desktop/authenticating-to-github-in-github-desktop) which will help manage credentials and all the different actions used in the course. 

Why is github desktop is your choice (Chatgpt to help):

* **GitHub Desktop handles login for you.**
  When you sign in through the app, it opens a web-based OAuth flow (your browser), then securely stores a token locally. This means you donâ€™t need to deal with `git config credential.helper`, `ssh keys`, or `gh auth login` manually.

* **Behind the scenes:**
  GitHub Desktop still uses Git under the hood. Normally on the CLI youâ€™d need to:

  * Set up **SSH keys** or
  * Configure a **personal access token (PAT)** for HTTPS.

  Desktop does this transparently by using the stored OAuth token whenever Git needs authentication.

* **Where it helps:**

  * No repeated username/password prompts.
  * No need to copy PATs or manage SSH keys manually.
  * Cross-platform (Windows/macOS/Linux) so it bypasses common OS credential manager headaches.

* **Where it doesnâ€™t fully solve things:**

  * If you switch to command line Git outside of GitHub Desktop, youâ€™ll still need to configure authentication (PAT/SSH) separately.
  * If you need advanced Git features (custom credential helpers, enterprise setups, automation), youâ€™ll still have to touch the CLI.

ðŸ‘‰ So: GitHub Desktop **solves authentication for itself** and makes Git "just work" in the GUI. But if you jump back into terminal Git, the Desktop login wonâ€™t automatically cover you unless your OS credential manager has synced with it.

</panel>

Also based on your operating system you could try the follow fix (Generated with chatgpt and the prompt below) :

I entered the username and PAT and received the message of "Authentication failed". I created a new PAT, reentered the username and new PAT and still received the message of "Authentication failed".
'''

## ðŸ”¹ Windows (SourceTree + GitHub PAT)

### Step 1: Clear old GitHub credentials

1. Open **Control Panel â†’ Credential Manager**.
2. Go to **Windows Credentials**.
3. Find entries related to `github.com` (under *Generic Credentials*).
4. Remove them.

---

### Step 2: Make sure youâ€™re using System Git

1. Open **SourceTree â†’ Tools â†’ Options â†’ Git tab**.
2. Select **Use System Git** (not Embedded Git).
3. Apply and restart SourceTree.

---

### Step 3: Re-add GitHub account with PAT

1. In SourceTree, go to **Tools â†’ Options â†’ Authentication**.
2. Remove any old GitHub accounts.
3. Click **Add** â†’ Choose *GitHub* â†’ Choose *HTTPS*.
4. When prompted for username/password:

   * **Username** â†’ your GitHub username (not email).
   * **Password** â†’ your PAT.

If SourceTree rejects it, you can instead let Windows Credential Manager store it:

'''bash
git credential-manager-core erase
git credential-manager-core store
'''

and then retry push/pull once in SourceTree.

---

## ðŸ”¹ Mac (SourceTree + GitHub PAT)

### Step 1: Clear old GitHub credentials

1. Open **Keychain Access**.
2. Search for `github.com`.
3. Delete any entries.

---

### Step 2: Switch Git in SourceTree

1. Open **SourceTree â†’ Preferences â†’ Git**.
2. Select **System Git**.
3. Restart SourceTree.

---

### Step 3: Re-add GitHub account with PAT

1. Go to **SourceTree â†’ Preferences â†’ Accounts**.
2. Remove any old GitHub entries.
3. Add a new one:

   * Hosting Service: **GitHub**
   * Protocol: **HTTPS**
   * Authentication: **Basic**
   * Username: your GitHub username
   * Password: your **PAT**

If SourceTree refuses to accept the PAT in GUI, you can set it via terminal:

'''bash
git credential-osxkeychain erase
git credential-osxkeychain store
'''

and then retry push/pull in SourceTree.

I have attached my yml file for your reference in the code block below. As per the error, you did not provide enough permissions which suggests you are missing the chmod +x which is the command used in linux to provide permission. You can remove the text-ui-test since it is no longer required after you implemented JUnit.

'''yml
name: Java CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [ master ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ master ]

jobs:
  build:

    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v3

    - name: Set up JDK 17
      uses: actions/setup-java@v3
      with:
        java-version: '17'
        distribution: 'temurin'

    - name: Grant execute permission for gradlew
      run: chmod +x gradlew
    - name: Build with Gradle
      run: ./gradlew build
    - name: Run tests with Gradle
      run: ./gradlew test
    - name: Run checkstyle
      run: ./gradlew checkstyleMain checkstyleTest
'''

>         run: chmod +x runtest.sh && ./runtest.sh
> '''

I learned a new area of PE testing today. To summarise for other thread readers, the bugs are (from what I have gathered through the current string of messages), best classified as `NotInScope`. Since they are technically bugs that users might face, and the application should help the user to the fullest, even a documentation suggestion could help the user debug. 

An honourable mention to a suggested fix from my teammate: Give the user the ability to pick the data directory. Debugging such an issue become much easier with a proper pipeline in-place. Although manually changing application permissions could resurface the issue, it is more transparent to the user. 

Ill keep the thread open for a while longer as I am learning quite a few new testing ideologies, feel free to share some other external factors experienced, if I find more I will add them as my last message and close this thread.

**1. :fas-info-circle: Guidance on responding to severity downgrade**
</div>

I have reported two types of bugs to a team (which they argue should be downgraded) and need guidance on what the severity should be like. I have both reported them as medium/high earlier.

1. Application does not gracefully handle typical invalid input

On some commands, I reported that there are cases where when an invalid input is provided (not an extreme case, e.g. just a typo), the UI doesn't respond at all due to the system not gracefully handling internal errors. I have no feedback from a user perspective, and have to check either the terminal output filled with Java errors or the user guide to see what's wrong (though, checking the user guide doesn't tell me specifically what might be wrong with my command). 

The team argues that this invalid case is rare edge case behaviour, and only causes minor inconvenience as the user would naturally investigate themselves on what's wrong through other available commands. Indeed, other commands can provide some clarity on the valid/invalid inputs. I somewhat see their perspective, as I did naturally investigate myself as to what went wrong given the UI response failure. But I don't know if this makes sense for it to be downgraded to a severity.Low, especially that this is a bug involving an uncaught error and the lack of a UI response completely. As a developer, I would find this issue critical, especially for a simple error like a typo in the command, but at the same time I somewhat see their point of this technically being recoverable as well.

2. Application does not start with correct sample data

The application restricts contacts to have certain non-empty attributes upon creation, but the sample data it starts with breaks this rule pretty glaringly (every contact generated breaks the rule). IMO, this is at least a medium as it causes immediate confusion for pretty much everyone starting up the app for the very first time. However, the team does argue that the UG makes this restriction clear throughout. This does allow users to continue to use the application, but the sample data remains erroneous until they are eventualy deleted. Is this a major inconvenience? What does the teaching team think this should be rated as?

In general, the common confusion I have with rating bugs w.r.t. to their severity is the 'inconvenience' caused. Are bugs that are 'severe' at point of discovery (very confusing / misleading at first) but are technically recoverable s.t. users can technically keep using their application w/ valid inputs considered 'severe'? If not, I assume it would depend on how easily the user can also continue to use the application (can make logical leaps as to what's wrong)? If so, as long as they follow the UG to a tee, would it then be considered as a low/medium rather than a medium/high?
</panel>

**2. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’Ž [Sharing a new concept + discussion] Reflection vs Factory Pattern**
</div>

Hello! As we've been progressing with the tP, I've chanced upon an interesting Java concept not taught here nor 2030S that I thought can be useful:

[Java Reflection](https://www.baeldung.com/java-reflection#bd-Constructors)

### Context
For context, during development we have a code snippet that can be SLAP-ed harder but it also has a dependency on our Predicate subclasses. We can abstract these repeated codes to a form like this:

```
<T> Predicate<T> producePredicate(Class<? extends Predicate> predicateClassMetadata, Integer satelliteData) ``{``
    validate();
    compute();
    Constructor<?> constructor =  predicateClassMetadata.getConstructor(Integer.class);
    Predicate<T> instance = constructor.newInstance(satelliteData);
``}``

```
### Personal Thoughts
At first glance this seems pretty powerful, I instantly drew links to the factory pattern & LoD.

Pros: 
- In comparison to the factory pattern, it seems like we don't need class overhead and we can just express production via 1 method and proper usage of generics.
- This enables late binding so it seems friendly for plugin type use cases.

Cons:
- Law of Demeter is SEVERELY violated. With the metadata, we can inspect/use a stranger's data/functionality as and when.
- Defensive programming overhead is required because of dynamic typing, with that comes performance tradeoffs.

### Discussion questions

1. What concrete use cases/situations would it be appropriate to use this double-edged feature of Java?
3. How would UML diagrams such as class diagrams (static) and an object diagram (dynamic) affected if this is used?
</panel>

1. For my project, I did not follow @Gareth2YuSheng and instead opted to use Java's own library of exceptions like this:

```   
public String execute(TaskList taskList) throws IllegalArgumentException,
            NullPointerException, DateTimeParseException ``{``
    ...
``}``
```

The rationale behind this design was because I felt that there wasn't a need to make custom exceptions as existing exceptions are descriptive enough to cover the kinds of exceptions I am checking for. It should be noted as well that this decision has its pros and cons as well: 

- Pros: Reduced overhead of exception classes being created & familiarity with the thrown exceptions. 
- Cons: Potential ambiguity in semantics (It can be managed somewhat if documentations specify when these kinds of exceptions are thrown, see below)
    - If you were to use custom exceptions, it would directly map to your program's business logic, completely eliminating ambiguity.

```
/**
 * Creates a new Task object based on the user's request.
 * @param taskList The task list to add the new task to.
 * @return A new Task object of the specified type.
 * @throws IllegalArgumentException If the task type is not recognized.
 * @throws NullPointerException If any of the required fields are missing.
 * @throws DateTimeParseException If the date format is incorrect.
 */
 @Override
 public String execute(TaskList taskList) throws IllegalArgumentException,
          NullPointerException, DateTimeParseException 
```


2. @Gareth2YuSheng and @chuckyang123 worded it nicely as well. I would like to add on that in more complex systems, exceptions can also take this form which is more elegant than if you were to just use plain if-else statements

```
try ``{``
    ...
``}`` catch (UnknownCommandException e) ``{``
    ui.showMessage("Error:" + e.getMessage())
``}`` catch (ProcessingException e) ``{``
     ui.showMessage("Error:" + e.getMessage())
    ... // Extra clean up logic
``}``
```

3. For me I think you won't be penalised as you met the minimal requirements. I do think its fine to mix exceptions and if-else statements as well. Though to elaborate on what the website says on **_when_** to use exceptions versus if-else statements, I would use exceptions when:

- I know this "case" of inputted data will disrupt crash my program or produce a very weird output
- I know this section of code may produce to me a 'unexpected' output that my program cannot handle

Your if-else statements are used to handle normal program flow, with **_standard conditions and inputs_**.
</panel>

**9. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡Java Formatter Setting for switch-case indentation**
</div>

Took me some time to find the setting to disable indent for each case in switch statements. 
as in:
```
switch ``{``
case: ...
``}``
```
instead of:
```
switch ``{``
    case: ...
``}``
```

So, for anyone looking as well, here's the line on your intellij-java-google-style.xml to ctrl-f:
`<setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.indent_switchstatements_compare_to_switch" value="false"/>`

For those trying to find the google java style guide .xml file, it can be downloaded here: https://google.github.io/styleguide/intellij-java-google-style.xml

<div slot="header">

**13 :fas-comment:**
</div>

I do believe another factor to consider is whether the modification follows your intended JSON format as well. E.g. If the tester abides by the JSON format set out by the application, but there is still a bug that arises, it may indicate that the application itself may be at fault as it failed to handle the data correctly. 

From the [level of support required:](https://se-education.org/addressbook-level3/UserGuide.html#editing-the-data-file)
> Caution: If your changes to the data file makes its format invalid, AddressBook will discard all data and start with an empty data file at the next run. Hence, it is recommended to take a backup of the file before editing it.
Furthermore, certain edits can cause the AddressBook to behave in unexpected ways (e.g., if a value entered is outside of the acceptable range). Therefore, edit the data file only if you are confident that you can update it correctly.

Essentially means that
* If the JSON format is invalid and you discard all data, that is fine
* Invalid values are handled correctly when loaded from the save file (ref point 1)

In that sense, I do believe that if the application cannot detect that there is something wrong, it will constitute a bug (as the user clearly didn't realise that there is something wrong too).
</panel>

Personally, sounds like a `NotInScope`. Essentially it comes down to how easy it even is for a user to activate the `clear` command. If your team's application does not offer tab completion (which means you cannot easily achieve `clear`+`enter keypress` with minimal human actions), the user would have had to **wilfully** type `c` `l` `e` `a` `r`, then hit enter.

or copy `clear`, paste it into the command box, and press enter

Which to me, does not require a safeguard (the confirmation step) as the user has had to have the intention to type it. Additionally, if your application makes backups for every command executed or provides undo functionality, it is even more irrelevant.

Just up to how you want to justify and challenge tester issues.

**1. :fas-info-circle: Question about time control in exam**
</div>

## My experience doing the test paper

The questions which references models drew in part 1 of the exam came slightly later in the exam(due to randomization), and I sped through most of them with relative easy, as they mostly require looking at my drawn models and finding what matches properly, so (unless the actual exam makes them significantly more difficult) it would be inaccurate to say that they are of the "same difficulty". 

## How do we properly estimate how much time to take then

Considering we cannot return to previous questions or skip questions, pacing is therefore key, but if there is a significant portion 5-10/30 of the questions that will take significantly less time than 2 minutes, a 2 minutes per question strategy is therefore inappropriate. So, for most students, this will come down to luck then? If you get the part 1 questions early, you can more accurately estimate how much time to take for the rest of the paper, but if you get it late, then you'll have to either:
1. speed through most of the paper at an optimistic (2 - 2:30 / question pace)
2. hope that they are of similar difficulty as the test paper, and that there is enough of them to create a buffer that allows you to spend more time on the rest of the paper.
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**11 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Hi @pranav3142 , thanks for the suggestion!

@damithc I found the issue with the assistance of @rk2k3. The issue was building the project with the following Gradle dependencies:

''' gradle
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
'''

# Root Cause
1. Incorrect JavaFX classifier

2. The dependencies specify classifier: `mac`, which is for Intel macOS binaries.

3. On Apple Silicon, apparently the JVM cannot load these libraries.

4. The correct classifier should be `mac-aarch64`

# Solution
**1. Update the classifier**

'''
implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-base:$javaFxVersion:mac-aarch64"
implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-controls:$javaFxVersion:mac-aarch64"
implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-fxml:$javaFxVersion:mac-aarch64"
implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-graphics:$javaFxVersion:mac-aarch64"
'''
_I used string notation here but map notation also works:_
`implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac-aarch64'`

**2. Use this SDK in File > Project Structure > Project > SDK**
<img width="433" height="45" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/18f58a90-6bcf-4849-a1e0-3d87b8fde6c9" />

**Full Dependency:**
'''
dependencies ``{``
    String jUnitVersion = '5.4.0'
    String javaFxVersion = '17.0.7'

    // JavaFX dependencies
    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-base:$javaFxVersion:win"
    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-base:$javaFxVersion:mac-aarch64"  // Apple Silicon
    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-base:$javaFxVersion:linux"

    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-controls:$javaFxVersion:win"
    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-controls:$javaFxVersion:mac-aarch64"
    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-controls:$javaFxVersion:linux"

    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-fxml:$javaFxVersion:win"
    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-fxml:$javaFxVersion:mac-aarch64"
    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-fxml:$javaFxVersion:linux"

    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-graphics:$javaFxVersion:win"
    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-graphics:$javaFxVersion:mac-aarch64"
    implementation "org.openjfx:javafx-graphics:$javaFxVersion:linux"

    implementation 'com.fasterxml.jackson.core:jackson-databind:2.7.0'
    implementation 'com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype:jackson-datatype-jsr310:2.7.4'

    testImplementation "org.junit.jupiter:junit-jupiter-api:$jUnitVersion"
    testRuntimeOnly "org.junit.jupiter:junit-jupiter-engine:$jUnitVersion"
``}``
'''
</panel>

'''gradle

    ``}``
``}``
'''

Yes, JavaDoc comments for overridden methods can be omitted.
> You MUST write header comments for all classes, public methods. But they can be omitted for the following cases:
> i. Getters/setters
> ii. When overriding methods (provided the parent method's Javadoc applies exactly as is to the overridden method)
> 
> Reference: https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/intermediate.html#comments

That being said, sometimes the overridden method is not sufficiently described by the JavaDoc comment of the function that it overrides. In these situations, it is still recommended to write a JavaDoc comment to explain why the specific method is overridden.
</panel>

This is possible on windows as well:

'''

<div slot="header">

**5 :fas-comment:**
</div>

For composition, it's the whole-part relationship. The whole is made up of the parts. When you delete the whole, the parts of course will be gone. For example, a book is made of chapters. If you throw away the book, the chapters are gone.

For aggregation, it's the contained-container relationship. The contained is only inside the container but not part of the container. For example, you bought a kiwi box. You then throw away the box and keep the kiwi.

In the context of OOP, the kiwi will still exist regardless of the existence of the box, similar to a normal generic association. What's the point for us to show aggregation if it's just like any other association? On the other hand, composition is a stronger association. The whole can't exist without the parts. The parts define the whole. What is a book without any chapters? But the kiwi surely remains after you throw away the box.

</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/142#issuecomment-3256538686" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**6 :fas-comment:**
</div>

A class diagram defines the rule of relationships between classes. It shows the static structure, abstract and timeless.
An object diagram is a snapshot of the actual relationships between objects in action. It shows the static structure and time-specific.

The main key here is static. Dependency is transient(temporary). It's fleeting and not important. It's like taking a photograph of a group of people; the photo shows who is in the room and where they are standing (their state), but it doesn't capture the brief conversation one person is having with another at that exact instant. Imagine how convoluted and trivial it is to draw speech balloons on the photo.

I think it just simply not the focus of UML.
</panel>

This error seems like it is a problem within your `MainWindow.fxml`, could you send what is in your `MainWindow.fxml` file?

Edit: To add on to this, your `MainWindow.fxml` should not have `&lt;fx.root>` if you meant to use it as an anchor pane
'''fxml
&lt;fx.root>
&lt;!-- Code here -->
&lt;/fx.root>
'''

Instead, the structure should be something like:
'''fxml
&lt;AnchorPane fx:controller="``{``location.to.MainWindow``}``">
&lt;!-- Code here -->
&lt;/AnchorPane>
'''

Take note ```{``location.to.MainWindow``}``` is the location of `MainWindow.java` from `src/main/java` onwards (e.g. if the file is at `src/main/java/duke/ui/MainWindow.java`, you should put in `duke.ui.MainWindow.java`.

Also note that the example start tag for `&lt;AnchorPane>` is incomplete as there is as it required other mandatory attributes like `xmlns:fx`.
</panel>

Even though `"F"`, `"T"`, and `"D"` all cause the function to return `true`, the specification may treat them as distinct valid flags, which we should put them into different class. As for `["f","t","d"]` they are considered as invalid input due to lower case thus placed in the same EP

 the implementation may look like this:

'''java
if (s.equals("F")) return true;
if (s.equals("T")) return true;
if (s.equals("D")) return true;
return false;
'''

Then:

* `"F"` triggers one branch
* `"T"` triggers a different branch
* `"D"` triggers the third branch

Different branches â†’ different behaviour â†’ different EP.

They are in same equivalence class only if code treated them identically, such as:

'''java
switch (s) ``{``
  case "F":
  case "T":
  case "D":
    return true;
``}``
'''

**4. :fas-info-circle: Should Command and Parsed stay nested inside Parser, or be separate Java files?**
</div>

In my current design, Iâ€™ve kept both the Command enum and the Parsed record inside the Parser class, like this:

'''java
public class Parser ``{``

    // ... parsing methods ...

    public enum Command ``{``
        BYE, LIST, MARK, UNMARK, DELETE, TODO, DEADLINE, EVENT
    ``}``

    public record Parsed(Command cmd, String args) ``{`` ``}``
``}``
'''
I kept both Command and Parsed inside the Parser class because they are tightly coupled to the parsing process and are not intended to be reused elsewhere.

Command only exists to represent the set of keywords that the Parser can recognise.

Parsed is just a simple container for the result of parsing (cmd + args).

By nesting them inside Parser, it is clear that they are part of the parsing logicâ€™s domain, not general-purpose classes. This improves encapsulation: other parts of the code can still access them (Parser.Command, Parser.Parsed) when needed, but their scope and meaning stay closely tied to parsing.

Would this be considered good OOP practice (since they are conceptually tied to parsing)?

Or should I instead move Command and Parsed into their own separate .java files for better structure and maintainability? Also, is the use of the record feature in Java allowed?
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/39#issuecomment-3204053015" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**5 :fas-comment:**
</div>

My personal opinion is that this boils down to scope, readability, and reusability.

If the helper logic is very short, self-contained, and only used once or twice in the same method, a lambda is perfectly fine. It can make your code concise and avoid cluttering the class with too many small methods.

On the other hand, if the logic is longer, used in multiple places, or could benefit from having a descriptive name, then it is usually clearer to declare it as a separate method. That way, it is easier to test, reuse, and understand at a glance.

The best choice depends on which option makes your code more readable and maintainable. In practice, I use lambda for quick inline behaviour testing, then extract it into a named method later if it grows or is reused.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/87#issuecomment-3233676884" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**6 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Thanks everyone, for pitching in and sharing your perspectives ðŸ™ 

Really appreciate the variety of views here. Itâ€™s helpful to see how some of you prefer encapsulating related types (like `Command` and `Parsed`) directly inside the Parser for cohesion and to avoid misuse, while others lean towards separation for clarity, maintainability, and extensibility as the project scales.

I think the key takeaway is that both approaches are valid in Java (especially since Java 17 gives us more modern features like record), and the â€œbestâ€ choice depends on the context:

1) If the types are tightly coupled and unlikely to be reused elsewhere, nesting can make sense.
2) If you expect the commands/enums to grow in number or be reused, separating them into their own files may be a cleaner and more extensible design.

Iâ€™ll weigh both sides carefully for my own implementation. Thanks again for all the thoughtful input!
</panel>

Like prof mentioned, JUnit tests donâ€™t have to be limited to methods that return values; what matters is whether youâ€™re testing the expected outcomes of your code. In our project, that can mean testing **state changes**, **exceptions**, or even **side effects**, not just return values.

Some examples from my own code:

**State changes:** after running TaskList.add() and TaskList.remove(), I check that the size updates and the correct task was removed.
'''java
TaskList list = new TaskList(new ArrayList&lt;>());
Todo t1 = new Todo("read book");
list.add(t1);
assertEquals(1, list.size());
assertSame(t1, list.get(0));
Task removed = list.remove(0);
assertSame(t1, removed);
assertEquals(0, list.size());
'''

**Exceptions:** for parsing, I check that invalid input is rejected.
'''java
assertThrows(MalformedArgumentsException.class, () ->
    Parser.splitDeadlineArgs("return book")); // missing /by
'''

**Conversions / logic:** for parseIndexOrThrow, I test that it correctly converts 1-based user input into 0-based indices, and that out-of-range inputs throw.
'''java
assertEquals(0, Parser.parseIndexOrThrow("1", 3));
assertThrows(ChattyException.class, () ->
    Parser.parseIndexOrThrow("4", 3)); // > size
'''

So even though the switch cases themselves donâ€™t return values, you can still write meaningful tests by verifying their effects on TaskList, or by checking that the right exceptions are thrown when inputs are invalid.

</panel>

Here are my two cents, even with an abstract class there is also nothing stopping you from having your child command class inheriting from this abstract class and implementing another interface as an extension? Yes it prevents you from inheriting another abstract class but I don't think it is as limiting as you imagine?

One benefit I can think of from having future edits all be in this abstract class would be easier readability for whoever you pass your code to. I can imagine if you were to have implementations and abstract classes as extensions for those implementations to be inherited by other classes the code may be unnecessarily messy as compared to having all functions in one place?

However, after working on it for a while, i realised that it is some what inefficient to make exception cases 1 by 1 using if commands for each scenario.

An abstract class would be more representative of a "is-a" relationship between the parent class and the child classes as compared to an interface which is more like a "can-do" relationship. While interface can allow for greater flexbility, they could be shared among classes that are not related but just share a certain property. In this case since all variation of a command is a command, it would be more clearly represented as an abstract class.
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**3. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡Forked the wrong repo?**
</div>

## Preamble

Forked the wrong repo and only realized this after pushing all your commits / increments? I happened to be in this position and I wanted to refork whilst preserve my existing commits / tags. I can't seem to anything regarding this on the [course website](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/) so I just wanted to share what I did exactly to resolve this.

## Resolving

### Step 1: Delete your current fork

This step is safe as you should have a local copy on your machine.

a. Click on Settings
<img width="236" height="360" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fdeeeffc-798d-45a5-b6f7-ba0e5105e995" />

b. Ensure General tab is selected
<img width="245" height="369" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/21909a9f-e7ee-4240-8a85-7654013e159c" />

c. Scroll down to delete your current fork
<img width="223" height="362" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fde19bd7-7f50-42cd-9bb2-b62f59f4ad2b" />

### Step 2: Refork from the correct repo

a. Navigate to the correct repo and fork
<img width="230" height="363" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/97312e0f-e547-42a1-bb67-c6b632d9c71e" />

b. Name it `ip` and ensure that `Copy the master branch` is unchecked.
<img width="311" height="464" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/dd8a35e6-6f4d-4607-9be0-197561ee5d05" />

### Step 3: Pull from the updated fork to your local repo
a. Run `git remote -v` to ensure your local repo is still pointed to remote. There should be no change here as we are using the same repo name of `ip`.
<img width="817" height="233" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/23953aec-6376-4019-a549-fbb7412b82ed" />

b. Run `git config pull.rebase false` to tell Git that you want to merge the changes when facing divergent branches.

> When you set git config pull.rebase false, you explicitly tell Git to avoid using the rebase strategy when pulling changes. Instead, it ensures that Git will always merge the changes. This configuration is particularly useful if you want to maintain the exact history of changes, including merge commits.

Stolen from [Graphite](https://graphite.dev/guides/git-config-pull-rebase-false)

<img width="613" height="120" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/804bfca6-5967-4f6e-bfc5-74ed5e24bae9" />

c. Run `git pull`
<img width="631" height="202" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ee4eda0a-d529-47d9-b0c5-ad2f03a0ec5e" />

### Step 4: Push to the new fork

a. Run `git push origin` to push all your existing commits
<img width="631" height="283" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bf7275d0-f1f5-4524-acd4-1f3f453a37ee" />

b. Run `git push --tags origin` to push all your existing tags
<img width="611" height="329" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8d09e43a-5385-48e6-a384-ab68d41cc5b4" />

**2. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡Automatically format code to obey checkstyle rules**
</div>

Using the [spotless](https://github.com/diffplug/spotless) formatter, you can configure formatting rules to obey the checkstyle rules. You can also make it run as a pre-commit hook so that your code gets automatically formatted before committing any changes. This ensures consistency in the codebase and can reduce merge conflicts and noise in git diffs.

First, add the spotless plugin to your `build.gradle` along with these settings
```
plugins ``{``
    ...
    id("com.diffplug.spotless") version "7.2.1"
``}``
...
spotless ``{``
  java ``{``
    cleanthat()
    eclipse().configFile("./config/eclipse-formatter.xml")
    importOrder("java.", "javax.", "org.", "com.", "")
    removeUnusedImports()
    formatAnnotations()
    trimTrailingWhitespace()
  ``}``
``}``
```
Next, create the file `./config/eclipse-formatter.xml` and add these formatting rules:
```
<\?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<profiles version="12">
  <profile kind="CodeFormatterProfile" name="CheckstyleCompatible" version="12">
    &gt;!-- Line length -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.lineSplit" value="120"/>

    &gt;!-- Indentation -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.tabulation.char" value="space"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.tabulation.size" value="4"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.indentation.size" value="4"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.continuation_indentation" value="2"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.continuation_indentation_for_array_initializer" value="1"/>

    &gt;!-- Braces placement (K&R style, matches LeftCurly/RightCurly rules) -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.brace_position_for_type_declaration" value="end_of_line"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.brace_position_for_method_declaration" value="end_of_line"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.brace_position_for_anonymous_type_declaration" value="end_of_line"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.brace_position_for_block" value="end_of_line"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.brace_position_for_enum_constant" value="end_of_line"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.brace_position_for_switch" value="end_of_line"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.brace_position_for_array_initializer" value="end_of_line"/>

    &gt;!-- Whitespace around operators, keywords, etc. -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_after_comma_in_method_declaration_parameters" value="insert"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_after_comma_in_method_invocation_arguments" value="insert"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_after_comma_in_alloc_exp" value="insert"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_after_comma_in_enum_constant_arguments" value="insert"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_after_comma_in_type_arguments" value="insert"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_after_comma_in_type_parameters" value="insert"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_after_comma_in_annotation" value="insert"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_after_comma_in_array_initializer" value="insert"/>

    &gt;!-- No extra spaces inside parens -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_after_opening_paren_in_method_invocation" value="do not insert"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_before_closing_paren_in_method_invocation" value="do not insert"/>

    &gt;!-- One statement per line -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.format_guardian_clause_on_one_line" value="false"/>

    &gt;!-- Import order (STATIC â†’ java/javax â†’ org.* â†’ com.*) -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.import_order" value="java;javax;org;com"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_before_semicolon" value="do not insert"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_after_semicolon" value="insert"/>

    &gt;!-- Wrapping (operators at new line, matches OperatorWrap rules) -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.wrap_before_binary_operator" value="true"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.alignment_for_binary_expression" value="16"/>

    &gt;!-- Indentation for array initializers -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.alignment_for_arguments_in_array_initializer" value="16"/>

    &gt;!-- Indentation for switch/case -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.indent_switchstatements_compare_to_switch" value="false"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.indent_switchstatements_compare_to_cases" value="true"/>

    &gt;!-- Control colon spacing -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_before_colon_in_case" value="do not insert"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.insert_space_before_colon_in_default" value="do not insert"/>

    &gt;!-- Enable wrapping of assignments -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.alignment_for_assignment" value="16"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.wrap_before_assignment_operator" value="false"/>

    &gt;!-- Alignment for method declarations -->
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.alignment_for_throws_clause_in_method_declaration" value="16"/>
    <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.indent_wrapped_throwing_clause" value="true"/>
  </profile>
</profiles>
```

As stated in #366, there is a checkstyle rule that erroneously flags lambda declarations, go to `config/checkstyle/checkstyle.xml` and delete these lines (around line 338 iirc):
```
<module name="SeparatorWrap">
  &gt;!-- Checks that the ",", "]", "[", "...", ";", "(" is at the previous end of line in a line wrap. -->
  <property name="tokens" value="COMMA, RBRACK, ARRAY_DECLARATOR, ELLIPSIS, SEMI, LPAREN"/>
  <property name="option" value="eol"/>
</module>
```

Now whenever you run `./gradlew spotlessApply`, it will apply all these formatting rules, run `./gradlew checkstyleMain checkstyleTest` to double check that it covered all the checkstyle rules. To add this as a pre-commit hook so that spotless runs before you commit any changes, create a new file at `.git/hooks/pre-commit` with these contents:
```
#!/bin/sh
echo "Running spotlessApply..."
gradle spotlessApply

git add -u

exit 0
```
Note that everyone in the team must add this locally if they want the pre-commit hook

Do update this thread if the formatting rules does not cover any checkstyle rules, leave a link to a branch where it fails and I will try to add new formatting rules to fix it.
</panel>
