<div slot="header">

**3. :fas-info-circle: checkstyle.xml SeparatorWrap module erroneously flags lambdas**
</div>

While trying to set up a formatter to obey the checkstyle rules, I ran into this checkstyle error that I could not fix with my formatter
'''
[ant:checkstyle] [ERROR] /home/user/programming/tp/src/test/java/seedu/address/logic/parser/AddressBookParserTest.java:94:17: '(' should be on the previous line. [SeparatorWrap]
'''

Here is the code snippet triggering the error
'''java
@Test
public void parseCommand_unrecognisedInput_throwsParseException() ``{``
    assertThrows(ParseException.class, String.format(MESSAGE_INVALID_COMMAND_FORMAT, HelpCommand.MESSAGE_USAGE),
            () -&gt; parser.parseCommand(""));
``}``
'''

At first I thought that it was complaining that the paranthesis for the lambda declaration is not on the previous line, and it expected the code to be like this:
'''java
@Test
public void parseCommand_unrecognisedInput_throwsParseException() ``{``
    assertThrows(ParseException.class, String.format(MESSAGE_INVALID_COMMAND_FORMAT, HelpCommand.MESSAGE_USAGE), ()
            -&gt; parser.parseCommand(""));
``}``
'''
Indeed this no longer produces any checkstyle errors, but there was no rule in my formatter to force lambda declarations to behave this way. I looked into the exact checkstyle module for this rule:
'''
 &lt;module name="SeparatorWrap">
  &lt;!-- Checks that the ",", "]", "[", "...", ";", "(" is at the previous end of line in a line wrap. -->
  &lt;property name="tokens" value="COMMA, RBRACK, ARRAY_DECLARATOR, ELLIPSIS, SEMI, LPAREN"/>
  &lt;property name="option" value="eol"/>
&lt;/module>
'''
It became clear that the purpose of this rule is to make sure separators like commas and parenthesis are placed at the correct positions when a single statement is broken up into multiple lines, so that code doesn't look like this:
'''
myMethod
(arg1
, arg2
, arg3);
'''
However, this also flags the left parenthesis of lambda declarations, even though it is common to have them at the start of the new line, just like in the first code snippet, and I also do not see anything in the coding standards about having lambdas on a new line. Is it fine to delete this checkstyle module, since my formatter will handle the cases it is trying to cover anyways?
</panel>

**3. :fas-info-circle: Bug found during PE only occurs on Windows**
</div>



Hi @damithc and CS2103T teaching team, 

Would need some help here dealing with how to respond to a bug raised to us that somehow only occurs on Windows.

One of our features involves a separate window popping up. 

On MacOS (the OS our team uses to test our product, and to implement), all windows are always correctly sized and accessible.

However, on Windows, for some reason the window that pops up goes out of bounds on the screen, and it causes some problems for the PE tester that used Windows.

How do we handle such a case? I feel that it is quite unfair to mark us down given that this was an issue we spent time on to specifically fix, and after testing we (very reasonably) thought it was fixed, and submitted it in the release. 

This was also during the gap between PE-D and v1.6, so there was limited time and limited code changes allowed to begin with, and going out of my way to obtain multiple devices with multiple different operating systems just to test a change is highly impractical and should not be expected of students in my opinion.

Also, to get another student to extensively test our app (which is making them go out of their way as well to spend an excessive amount of time to comprehensively test all these small little features on another OS) also sounds impractical to me.

Furthermore, we were given multiple green lights by the automated smoke testing emails from the CS2103 team, which gave us another false sense of security that our app was working fine on other operating systems (I do understand that the automated smoke testing does not do any actual tests on the functionality, but rather I am trying to say that this lowered our guard to comprehensively go out of our way (as detailed above) to test on other operating systems)


This seems to me like a flaw of the Windows operating system itself, and we are having some issues with how to classify such a bug report. Would this still count as a bug? Or can we say that the bug is not reproducible (under our team's working conditions) under response.CannotReproduce? 
</panel>

With week 7's introduction of a fork-based team development workflow, I was wondering if the following TDD-driven approach would be appropriate.

1. Person A picks up a feature F1 to work on
2. Person B writes the test cases for F1, and submits a PR to the main repo
3. Person A and C review person B's test cases and merges them with main repo
4. Person A creates the feature that has to adhere to the tests created and submits a PR
5. PR is reviewed by B and C before being accepted

Would this workflow be appropriate or practical to implement? For anyone with TDD or fork-based development experience, what challenges do you think we would face, and overall do you think this is recommended? Any feedback or discussions are welcome in this thread, thank you!

If there is a code like: 
```
try ``{``
    // do something
``}`` catch (catch nothing) ``{``
    // do nothing
``}`` finally ``{``
    // do something else
``}``
```
In my opinion, catching is used for spotting runtime errors. If we catch nothing, this code is essentially the same as:
```
// do something
// do something else
```
So, back to the question, I do not think it conflicts any coding standard. But this would downgrade the simplicity and readability of code, as it uses a redundant logic structure.

Adding on to kahei's point, Class A & B have an association relationship as Class A 'has a' Consumer&lt;List&lt;Class B>> field and therefore holds references to Class B instances. Class A can 'use' the Consumer to perform an action (implemented by the Consumer) on the List&lt;Class B>. Hence, Class A would not depend on Class B as it does not invoke any of Class B's methods. Instead, Class A would have a dependency relationship with the Consumer. 
</panel>

**2. :fas-info-circle: Arch install steps incorrect for gitmastery**
</div>

<img width="811" height="266" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/32b2983d-a221-4e70-8332-315978e09dcd" />

The install section of the page tells the user to use `sudo pacman -Syu gitmastery-bin` to install, but this does not work, as gitmastery is not in the [official Arch repositories](https://archlinux.org/packages/?sort=&arch=any&arch=x86_64&repo=Core&repo=Core-Testing&repo=Extra&repo=Extra-Testing&repo=Gnome-Unstable&repo=KDE-Unstable&repo=Multilib&repo=Multilib-Testing&repo=Testing&q=gitmastery-bin&maintainer=&flagged=):

<img width="1024" height="388" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/295e63bb-c24c-4c00-a446-b2680fa2d843" />

It is in the [arch user repository](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/gitmastery), but installing it with yay does not work. 

<img width="747" height="64" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/419feb9f-8e75-4839-a545-c583fc61517c" />

The issue is related to the PKGBUILD file. There seem to be typos, many references to $srdir but that variable does not exist, so it looks for the file in the root directory / instead. By replacing all $srdir with $srcdir, the installation works fine.

<img width="821" height="46" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/abf7e81d-5af6-46f5-ac63-6ed0e9b94404" />

## Overall steps to install gitmastery on arch
If you want to reproduce what I did:
1. Go to the [AUR page for gitmastery-bin](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/gitmastery-bin)
2. Clone the URL from the page (https://aur.archlinux.org/gitmastery-bin.git)
3. `cd` into directory
4.  Open up PKGBUILD and replace all instances of $srbuild with $srcbuild. I did this with vim, with `%s/srdir/srcdir/g`
5. Install with `makepkg -si`
6. Done

</panel>

To add on to @gnahuy123,

My mental model is that event-driven architecture is very much related to listeners and handlers that are quite common in GUIs/Webdev. So something like `button.listen(() -&gt; ``{``doThis()``}``` falls under event-driven because we attach a handler that transmits messages to other components once an event occurs.

While transaction processing is more related to say, [load balancing](https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/performance/what-is-load-balancing/). If you're unfamiliar with the concept you can read the link, but TL;DR it's where instead of sending requests directly to specific servers, you mediate requests with a server in the middle (the dispatcher). The dispatcher decides which server to send the request to based on metrics like server health, load, etc.

So I think the dispatcher in transaction-processing systems are inherently "heavier" - they include some sort of inherent logic to dynamically choose where the event goes. In contrast to event-driven dispatchers, which simply send messages to some predefined consumer. And yea, the dispatcher in transaction-processing systems get sent events directly by some actor, while in event-driven architectures the dispatcher directly attaches to the relevant section to get the events.

Not too sure if everything I said here is correct, so any clarifications would be welcome haha.
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**6 :fas-comment:**
</div>

I think you miscategorized this as MVC! You're looking at the observer pattern.

Most likely the UI classes here already have some mechanism to get the student list. It could be that they hold a copied  student list, so any changes in the original student list does not propagate to the UI directly. The update() method here is like a signal to the UI classes to "refresh" their view and obtain a new student list.

Another method that is possible (but not shown directly in the example here) is to have the update() method accept a student list as a parameter. This allows the UI classes to directly replace their view of student list on an update.

I think the key thing that you should be grasping from this is that the observer pattern allows a class to be notified immediately whenever another object goes through some change. What the listener does with this notification is implementation-level detail that can differ based on the use case.

I highly recommend reading [this article on refactoring.guru](https://refactoring.guru/design-patterns/observer)
</panel>

</panel>

Sorry to be clearer let me reiterate my points. The resched cmd has 2 versions.

1. (version 1) resched must be strictly in the format of _YYYY-MM-DD_ if you want to call the [_resched &lt;instruction_idx> YYYY-MM-DD_]. This version allows for the rescheduling to an earlier date if the user inputs an earlier date.
 
2. (version 2) resched can also be called in the form of _+numberOfDays (i.e. +3d, +6d etc.)_. In full, this would look like _[resched  &lt;instruction_idx> +3d]_. For this, you can only call + (plus) and not - (minus). I have realised this is somewhat of a limitation/loophole but the focus of this comment for now will just to make sure my chatbox can run on Windows/Linux OS', and not so much on the feature itself.

Thanks everybody. Hopeful for a Linux OS follow up soon.

To remove the folder from the remote repo but still keep it locally, you can do the following:
1. Add the folder to your `.gitignore` file. For example, add the line `/imgs`.
2. Untrack the files that are already in the repo (make sure you've committed everything else beforehand):
'''bash
git rm -rf --cached .
git add .
'''
This removes all files from the repository and adds them back (this time respecting the rules in your `.gitignore`).

3. Commit and push your changes. After that, the `imgs` folder will no longer appear in the remote repository, but it will remain in your local copy.

<div slot="header">

**5 :fas-comment:**
</div>

If `StudentList` is immutable, then as Harjun mentioned, the instance can be passed as a parameter to its `observerList` by using `update(StudentList newList)`.
It would be dangerous to pass a mutable reference of StudentList to random Observers.

Alternatively, the Observers could use their own way of communicating with the StudentList to retrieve the updates, like through a facade for the Model.
For the below example which doesn't use a facade (from MVC in textbook), instead of the `getData(id)` being called on StudentList, it could be the UI calling `getStudentData(id)` on the Model facade.
This allows the UI to not have a reference to `studentList`, but still be able to get updates from the new list.
Another design pattern to fix the flaw of mixing 2 design patterns.

<img width="794" height="436" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f9af650a-8495-498c-bae3-7ea16920e67d" />

<div slot="header">

**1. :fas-info-circle: Major rewriting/refactoring of existing components**
</div>

Is it considered within the scope of the tP to rewrite/refactor entire components?

To clarify, this is not about changing the overarching structure and architecture of the application. Things like the MVC architecture would be kept intact, and most of the abstraction boundaries around the rewritten/refactored components (e.g. the component interfaces) too will be kept intact. The goal here of rewriting/refactoring is not to change the overarching architecture, but to make existing components less coupled, better abstracted, and more performant.

I would assume this is not against tP grading rules, but would like to get some confirmation since it seems there isn't much detail about this in the tP grading page.

- - -

Some background information, if it helps:

I am particularly asking about rewriting the parsing component to make it easier to add new commands and add more flexibility in command structure. The current parser uses very inextensible syntax and follows very inefficient parsing techniques that involve scanning the same string over and over again. I would like to rewrite the parser and get it to use more well-established techniques (with better theoretical grounds) than the present implementation.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/100#issuecomment-3238949378" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**2 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Seems like you staged the file, but never committed it. I'm inferring it from the `new file: &lt;filename>` line after you typed `git status`.

My understanding is:
- Use `git rm` to stage deletion (and remove it from your working directory) if you have previously committed a file (file is presently being tracked) and would like to now delete it and stop tracking the file.
- If you have not previously committed a file, then `git rm` is a dangerous command because it deletes the file from your working directory as well, and deleting the file means git cannot retrieve the lost file for you since it has not previously saved any version of that file. The `-f` flag overrides this warning and forces removal.

If you had committed those files previously, then git would likely have let the commands you were having trouble with run and restore the files for you. The nice thing about git is that it often gives you the commands you need to type or the exact parts you need to fix. If you wanted to unstage the added file but keep the file in your working directory (safe for a file that has not yet been committed prior to this), doing `git restore --staged &lt;filename>` or `git rm --cached &lt;filename>` would've done the trick, as suggested by git.

The latter errors (`fatal: could not resolve HEAD`) are likely due to your repository not having an initial commit. HEAD presently doesn't point to any commit.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/115#issuecomment-3239324593" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**3 :fas-comment:**
</div>

I assume your intent is that you want to push local changes forcefully and overwrite what is on the remote. If you are sure that what you have locally is what you want reflected on the remote `master` branch and you do not care anymore about the commits on the remote that will be overwritten (probably whatever you were trying to get rid of by running `git reset`), then run `git push -f origin master` (add the `-f` flag to force push).
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/367#issuecomment-3366232798" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**4 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Yeah, I admit that I intend to do this mostly for didactic reasons; it isn't terribly difficult to write a simple recursive descent parser for the kinds of commands that are in scope for the tP. For other projects I'd agree, using a parser generator or an existing parsing solution is likely going to be better.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/367#issuecomment-3367744512" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**5 :fas-comment:**
</div>

> As an aside I feel like parsing commands as a grammar using recursive descent is overkill, I believe typical cli parsers are implemented as state machines like a lexer approach with regex

Some of our planned features (even if they are only low priority) depend on the grammar being sufficiently expressive (at least context-free/type-2). Nested brackets, for example, cannot be expressed in regular grammars, so DFAs/NFAs/regexes are insufficient.

Might be veering off topic already, but there are also other practical considerations that went into this (but part of why I am doing this to begin with is also to figure out what necessitates stronger parsers), like the ability to construct detailed error messages and the ability to easily prove correctness of the parser in implementing a particular grammar.

I do have both a lexer and parser ready from the iP, and after implementing them, I wouldn't say using recursive descent is overkill or requires significantly more effort than implementing a DFA/NFA, but it does let me, say, write more detailed error messages (to do that, the machine needs to 'remember' what production rule it was trying to apply).

> You may refactor tP code and change the design as you see fit, provided you do it incrementally. So, it should be fine to replace the parser with a different implementation.

Great! Thanks for the clarification.
</panel>

You probably haven't added your jdk location to your system PATH, which is why your device is unable to run java commands like javac.

### To fix this you can try:
1. Make sure to **download a JDK**, the course requires us to use **JDK 17** so should have already downloaded it if you followed the course instructions. If you haven't you can go to the oracle website and download it. The compressed archive should be sufficient to my knowledge.
2. Move the JDK archive to your preferred location on your device, in my case I place it in a folder like this
<img width="697" height="162" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4338a11e-d87e-4dfe-b281-511932b54aac" />
 
3. **Add the location of your JDK compressed archive to your PATH**, similar to how you followed the instructions to setup the Github CLI
This resolved the issue for me.

In my case I also ran the windows installer to install JDK 17 on my device but this error didn't resolve until I updated my PATH with the compressed archive. If you try these steps and it still doesn't work you can try installing the JDK on your device as well and try to run the javac command again.

1. Here is an example of a custom exception that I have made
'''java 
public class UnknownCommandException extends BBongException ``{``
    public UnknownCommandException() ``{``
        super("Unknown Command! B. Bong doesn't know what to do...");
    ``}``
    public UnknownCommandException(String message) ``{``
        super(message);
    ``}``
``}``

//Main.java
public static Command stringToCommand(String word) throws UnknownCommandException ``{``
        for (Command c : Command.values()) ``{``
            if (c.getCommandWord().equalsIgnoreCase(word)) ``{``
                return c;
            ``}``
        ``}``
        throw new UnknownCommandException();
    ``}``
'''

2. Firstly, I agree with what @chuckyang123 mentioned that by defining your own exceptions and controlling where you throw them, it is easier to see what went wrong in your code if used appropriately. Secondly, if you look at my example, I can hard code custom error messages into my exceptions so that when I throw them I can just throw back the error message, making my code a little but shorter like this:
'''java
try ``{``
        command = Command.stringToCommand(commandParts[0].toLowerCase());
    ``}`` catch (UnknownCommandException e) ``{``
        botErrorMessage(e.getMessage());
    ``}``
'''
rather than doing something like:
'''java
try ``{`` 
    ...
``}`` catch (Exception e) ``{``
    System.out.println("Something went wrong");
``}``
'''
As you can see it kinda just saves me from writing a error message every time I catch my exception and just uses its hard coded value.

3. I personally think its fine to mix if-else and exception handling as at the end of the day its your own design choice for your code, I personally do mix both as I like keeping errors and exceptions managed at a certain level without them leaking out to the main code.

Dependency means:
Class A uses Class B temporarily to perform some action.

Association class means:
A relationship between two classes that has its own data or behaviour.

A Student enrolls in a Course.
The relationship has attributes like grade, semester, etc.
So we model Enrollment as an association class.

User guide link: https://catisnotsodium.github.io/ip/
Which OS'es to test on: **Mac and Linux (WSL is ok)**
## Things to check specifically:
Before testing, make sure that you delete `data/cattis.txt` from your machine before testing.
To start the application, simply run `java -jar cattis.jar`.
### File storage works properly
To test, place these instructions below line-by-line (except the text behind `//` which is used to indicate the expected behavior).
```
list // must show <empty>
todo task1 // task should have one element
mark 2 // should get out-of-bound
mark 1 // should work properly
list // must show one task
delete 1 
list // must show <empty>
bye
```

### Calendar view
Simply type `calendar` to check if there is no visual bugs. This includes 
- Misaligned or overlapping UI elements in the calendar grid
- Inconsistent color schemes or unreadable text
- Navigation buttons (e.g., <, >) not functioning properly

To apply some seed values, you can simply add some basic instructions.
```
deadline iP Week 5 /by 2025-09-12
deadline iP Week 6 /by 2025-09-19
deadline iP Week 4 /by 2025-09-05
```

## Guide for testers:
* Post screenshots from your smoke tests (only for calendar view)
* Mention which OS you used for testing

4. Untick all options such as `Remove trailing spaces on:` & `Remove trailing blank lines at the end of saved files`
5. Press `Apply` then `OK` to save the setting.

Result:
IntelliJ will no longer remove trailing whitespaces when you save files.

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/542" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**1. :fas-info-circle: Clarification on responding and justifying duplicates**
</div>

Our team has a simple documentation error that we have accepted, but it is also very clearly repeated over 3 different issues. We have since marked the issues as duplicate using the sub issue feature and choosing one of them as the original (as per stated in the course instructions). 

Some clarifications needed: 

1. Do we need to respond to all 3 issues? Or will a response to the original issue suffice? 

2. How do we justify that they are duplicates without cross referencing the issues? Do i just describe the issues the same way? How will a responding tester be able to judge whether it is a duplicate without seeing the other issues, or will they be able to?

3. One of the issues has the wrong severity label. Do i refute it by responding to the issue directly, or just in the original issue? (I guess this is only a question if the answer to question 1 is that we only respond to the original issue)

Currently we have opted to reply to all 3 issues separately, with basically the same response for each, except with extra clarifications for the issue with severity change. Is this okay? 
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/89" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**2. :fas-info-circle: Commit conventions: Conflicting info on first letter capitalisation.**
</div>

The commit convention document provided mentioned that subject lines should start with a capital letter. However a few lines down they suggest to use "scope: change" format, with the given examples: 

Person class: remove static imports
Main.java: Remove blank lines
bug fix: Add space after name

All three examples have differing standards for where capitalisation is required...

Additionally, common convention found online (also provided by the doc) seems to encourage the use of prefixes like "feat: ", "fix: ", "perf: " etc to type our commits, which all violate the rule of capitalisation. 

Any help on this matter is greatly appreciated, as my commits are in shambles right now.
I've spent the summer writing the most diabolical commit messages for Orbital. Please let me redeem myself in this mod.  
</panel>

As such, since you are accepting the bug as is, no need to comment anything about the the parent bug, just include justification (and other comments you have) of the other duplicate bugs in the parent bug's response.

**1. :fas-info-circle: LOC calculation**
</div>

Hi teaching team, 

I'd like to clarify how the feature freeze LOC limit is calculated, specifically regarding aggregated changes and how they are assessed.

The rules state that the limit is on added/edited lines, and that deleting lines does not count as a change.

Given this, please consider the following scenario for a single developer:

PR 1 Merged: Adds +80 LOC (functional code). This initial merge exceeds the 50 LOC limit, creating a violation.

PR 2 Merged: Removes -40 LOC (functional code), **specifically deleting lines that were introduced in PR 1.**

In that case, how will this sequence be assessed against the feature freeze rules?

Option A: Does the system aggregate the net change (80 - 40 = 40 LOC), meaning the developer is now in adherence and the violation is cleared?

Option B: Or, because "deleting lines does not count as a change," does the system only track the additions? In this case, will it permanently show +80 LOC of changes, meaning the violation persists even after the cleanup (PR 2)?

We are unsure if the dashboard (and by extension grading) will reflect Option A (net change) or Option B (permanent violation based on initial addition).

<img width="485" height="53" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5b861d78-44aa-4151-8504-3ff5510099d2" />

For reference, here is what a sample graph from the repo looks like now (using feature freeze dashboard), where the blue triangle indicates +70 -15, while the sharp pink triangle indicates +0 -80; however due to the existence of the +70 from the first commit / PR we are not very sure how this change will be assessed.

If there are any existing features in the dashboard that are able to compute / evaluate overall changes do let us know too, and thank you for your help!

</panel>

This is a very interesting question. It feels more like functional programming rather than OOP, so I'm not sure if the concepts of association/dependency apply to this scenario. However, if one of them do, I would think that it is not an association because there isn't actually any reference to a List of Class B. Rather, Class A contains a reference to an unknown Class which satisfies the Consumer interface, and thus has an "accept" method which takes in a List of Class B. So while Class A is not related to Class B at all, we could probably say that Consumer&lt;Class B> is dependent on Class B
</panel>

I think it is good OOP practice to nest Command and Parsed inside Parser as they are both conceptually tied to Parser (ie. they are not used independently). By encapsulating them it can prevent accidental misuse outside the parsing context. Unless you anticipate reusing them in a different context, or if they become too complex to maintain, then I would consider separating them.

This is what I found online: Persistence: Associations are typically more persistent relationships, often represented by attributes or fields, while dependencies can be more temporary, such as a local variable within a method. From the given context, Class A contains the variable Consumer&lt;List&lt;Class B>>, signifying that it is an association relationship. However, if the variable is within a method, it can arguably be dependency.

</div>

I think the main advantage of the forking workflow is that it allows pull requests to be developed in parallel. Since we havenâ€™t encountered many complex scenarios yet, it may be difficult to visualise its benefits, but I believe this workflow provides greater flexibility. We can work on multiple features at the same time, or continue developing new ones while waiting for earlier pull requests to be reviewed and merged, which can prove to be highly useful, for instance, when dealing with a time crunch.

Another important aspect is that the master branch in each fork is usually meant to mirror the upstream master. This makes it easier to keep progress synchronised across team members and to clearly distinguish between stable code and ongoing development. If we made all changes directly in the master branch, we would lose this separation, which could lead to conflicts and confusion in larger or more complex team structures.

As for the second question, my understanding is that the changes will only appear in the team repoâ€™s master branch once the pull request has been reviewed and merged, usually by another team member. So the process is usually as follows: 

1. Submit a pull request from a separate branch in your fork.
2. Pull request gets merged into upstream's master by another team member.
3. You update your fork's local repo by pulling or fetching from the upstream master branch
4. The local repo now contains the changes automatically, without needing to re-merge the branch to your master manually
5. Push the local repo's master to the fork's remote to update your remote to the latest version of the codebase.

I think the videos in the website explain this process better than I did, so you can check them out at [tP Briefing (Part 2a -- v1.1, Workflow).](https://nus-cs2103-ay2526s1.github.io/website/schedule/week7/index.html) This was quite useful for me.

This is my current understanding, others may have additional insights to add.
</panel>

</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2526S1/forum/issues/163#issuecomment-3277261168" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**1 :fas-comment:**

Rah-Rah-Mitra's has done a good job identifying the root of the problem, but it isn't entirely correct.

The problem is not that the `gradlew` file cannot be executed, but rather the `runtest.sh` file. To fix this, you can either remove the last two sections which run `text-ui-test`, or modify the `runtest.sh` test to be this:

```
      - name: Perform IO redirection test (*NIX or macOS)
        if: runner.os == 'Linux' || runner.os == 'macOS'
        working-directory: $``{`` github.workspace ``}``/text-ui-test
        run: chmod +x runtest.sh && ./runtest.sh
```
